trans-unit.source: Declaratively instructs the .NET Framework to perform string validation on a configuration property.
You use the <xref:System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute> to decorate a configuration property.
This is to instruct the .NET Framework to validate the property using the <xref:System.Configuration.StringValidator> and pass to it the value of the decorating parameters.
You can apply <xref:System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute> objects to property types only.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute"></xref> class.
You use this constructor in the attributed model to ensure that the value assigned to the configuration-element property is of a string type.
Gets or sets the invalid characters for the property.
The string that contains the set of characters that are not allowed for the property.
Gets or sets the maximum length allowed for the string to assign to the property.
An integer that indicates the maximum allowed length for the string to assign to the property.
The selected value is less than <xref href="System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute.MinLength"></xref>.
Gets or sets the minimum allowed value for the string to assign to the property.
An integer that indicates the allowed minimum length for the string to assign to the property.
The selected value is greater than <xref href="System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute.MaxLength"></xref>.
Gets an instance of the <xref href="System.Configuration.StringValidator"></xref> class.

You use the <xref:System.Configuration.StringValidatorAttribute.ValidatorInstance%2A> property to perform string validation by calling its <xref:System.Configuration.StringValidator.Validate%2A> method.
A current <xref href="System.Configuration.StringValidator"></xref> settings in a <xref href="System.Configuration.ConfigurationValidatorBase"></xref> validator instance.
